# A Demand Function (Again)

.pull-left[

- A consumer's .shout[quantity demanded] (of good x), $q_x^D$ is a function of their .shout[demand for good x], which depends on current market prices and their income

$$q_x^D = D(m, p_x, p_y)$$

- We now want to examine how **quantity demanded for x** changes as each of these parameters change:

1. .whisper[Income effects] $\left(\frac{\Delta q_x^D}{\Delta m}\right)$: how $q_x^D$ changes with changes in income
2. .whisper[Cross-price effects] $\left(\frac{\Delta q_x^D}{\Delta p_y}\right)$: how $q_x^D$ changes with changes in prices of *other* goods (e.g. $y)$
3. .whisper[(Own) Price effects] $\left(\frac{\Delta q_x^D}{\Delta p_x}\right)$: how $q_x^D$ changes with changes in price (of $x)$
]

.pull-right[
.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/nw0v6bsho0ab4zq/choices.jpg?raw=1)
]
]

class: inverse, center, middle

# The (Own) Price Effect

---

# The (Own) Price Effect

.pull-left[

- .shout[Price effect]: change in optimal consumption of a good associated with a change in its price, holding income and other prices constant

$$\frac{\Delta q_x^D}{\Delta p_x} < 0$$


.whisper[The law of demand]: as the price of a good rises, people will tend to buy less of that good (and vice versa)
  - i.e. the price effect is negative!

]
.pull-right[
.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/o6l11dlc5ntiveq/pricetag.jpg?raw=1)
]
]

---

# Decomposing the Price Effect

- The price effect (law of demand) is actually the .onfire[net result of two effects]

--

- .shout[(Real) income effect]: change in consumption due to change in real purchasing power 

--

- .shout[Substitution effect]: change in consumption due to change in relative prices

--

$$\text{Price Effect} = \text{Real income effect} + \text{Substitution Effect}$$

---

class: inverse, center, middle
# (Real) Income Effect

---

# (Real) Income Effect

.pull-left[

- Suppose there is only 1 good to consume, $x$. You have a $100 income, and the price of $x$ is $10. You consume 10 units of $x$

- Suppose the price of $x$ falls to $5. Your now consume 20 units of $x$.

- This is the .shout[real income effect]: a change in the price of $x$ changes your .onfire[real income] or .onfire[purchasing power], the amount of goods you can buy

- Note your *actual* (nominal) income of $100 never changed!
]

.pull-right[

.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/f0pkglla38vsojx/flations.png?raw=1)
]

]

---

# (Real) Income Effect: Size


.pull-left[

- The *size* of the income effect depends on how large a *portion of your budget* you spend on the good

- **Large-budget items**:
    - e.g. Housing/apartment rent, car prices
    - Price increase makes you much poorer
    - Price decrease makes you much wealthier

- **Small-budget items**:
    - e.g. pencils, toothpicks, candy
    - Price changes don't have much of an effect on your wealth or change your behavior much

]

.pull-right[

.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/s6ypeqyuyslpe6v/rentapartments.jpg?raw=1)

![:scale 40%](https://www.dropbox.com/s/v1b3dbeom3k2hz8/pencil.png?raw=1)

]
]

class: inverse, center, middle
# Substitution Effect

---

# Substitution Effect

.pull-left[

- Suppose there are 1000s of goods, none of them are a major fraction of your budget

- Suppose the price of one good, $x$ increases

- The **real income effect** for $x$ is tiny (and negative)

- But you would consume *less* of $x$ relative to other goods because $x$ is now *relatively* more expensive

- That's the .shout[substitution effect]: consumption changes because of a change in **relative prices**
]

.pull-right[

.center[
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/dv8ce57s6azr8e8/groceryaisle.jpg?raw=1)

]
]

---

# Substitution Effect: Size


- The *size* of the substitution effect depends on how substitutable two goods are 	
.pull-left[

# Putting the Effects Together

---

# Putting the Effects Together

- .shout[Real income effect]: change in consumption due to change in real purchasing power
    - Can be positive (**normal goods**) or negative (**inferior goods**)
    - Lower price of $x$ means you can buy more $x$, $y$, or *both* (depending on your preferences between $x$ and $y$)

--

- .shout[Substitution effect]: change in consumption due to change in relative prices
    - If $x$ gets cheaper relative to $y$, consume  $\downarrow y$ (and $\uparrow x$)
    - This is always the same direction! $(\downarrow$ relatively expensive goods, $uparrow$ relatively cheaper goods)
    - This is why demand curves slope downwards!
    
--

$$\text{Price Effect} = \text{Real income effect} + \text{Substitution Effect}$$

---

# Real Income and Substitution Effects, Graphically I

.pull-left[

- Original optimal consumption $(A)$

]

.pull-right[

```{r}
points_pe<-tribble(
  ~letter, ~x, ~y,
  "A", 10, 15,
  "B", 20, 7.5,
  "C", 40, 15
)

IC_pe_1=function(x){150/x}
IC_pe_2=function(x){600/x}
BC_pe_subst=function(x){15-0.375*x}
BC_pe_1=function(x){30-1.5*x}
BC_pe_2=function(x){30-0.375*x}
```

```{r, fig.retina=3, fig.height=6}
ggplot(data.frame(x=c(0,10)), aes(x=x))+
  stat_function(fun=IC_pe_1, geom="line", size=2, color = "#453781FF")+
  stat_function(fun=BC_pe_1, geom="line", size=2, color = "red")+
    geom_label(aes(x=3,y=IC_pe_1(3)), color = "#453781FF", label=expression(u[1]), size = 6)+
    geom_label(aes(x=7,y=BC_pe_1(7)), color = "red", label=expression(paste(p[x],"=$5.00")), size = 5)+

  geom_point(data = subset(points_pe, letter=="A"),
             mapping=aes(x=x, y=y),
             size = 3)+
  geom_text_repel(data = subset(points_pe, letter=="A"),
             mapping=aes(x=x, y=y,
             label = letter),
             size = 6)+
  # A lines
  geom_segment(aes(x = 0, xend = 10, y = 15, yend=15), linetype="dotted", size=1)+
  geom_segment(aes(x = 10, xend = 10, y = 15, yend=0), linetype="dotted", size=1)+
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(0,80,10),
                     limits=c(0,80),
                     expand=expand_scale(mult=c(0,0.1)))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,80,10),
                     limits=c(0,80),
                     expand=expand_scale(mult=c(0,0.1)))+
  coord_cartesian(clip = "off")+
  labs(x = "x",
       y = "y",
       caption = expression(paste("Optima with ", u(x,y)==x^{0.5}*y^{0.5}, ", ", m==100, ", ", p[y]==3.33, sep=" ")))+
  theme_classic(base_family = "Fira Sans Condensed", base_size=20)
```

]

# Real Income and Substitution Effects, Graphically III

.pull-left[

.pull-right[

```{r, fig.retina=3, fig.height=6}
ggplot(data.frame(x=c(0,10)), aes(x=x))+
  stat_function(fun=IC_pe_1, geom="line", size=2, color = "#453781FF")+
```

# Real Income and Substitution Effects: Inferior Good

# Recap: Real Income and Substitution Effects

$$\text{Substitution Effect} + \text{Real Income Effect} = \text{Price Effect}$$

- .orange[Substitution effect]: is always in the direction of the cheaper good

- .green[Real Income effect]: can be positive (normal) or negative *inferior)

- Law of Demand/Demand curves slope downwards (.purple[Price effect]) mostly because of the substitution effect
    - Even (inferior) goods with negative real income effects overpowered by substitution effect

- Exception in the theoretical .shout[Giffen good]: negative R.I.E. $>$ S.E.
    - An upward sloping demand curve!

# Demand Schedule

.pull-left[

- .shout[Demand schedule] expresses the quantity of good a person would be willing to buy $(q_D)$ at any given price $(p_x)$

- Note: .onfire[each of these is a consumer's optimum at a given price!]
]

.pull-right[

```{r, echo=F, results="asis"}
tribble(
  ~"price", ~"quantity",
  10, 0,
  9, 1,
  8, 2,
  7, 3,
  6, 4,
  5, 5,
  4, 6,
  3, 7,
  8, 2,
  9, 1,
  10, 0
) %>%
  knitr::kable(., format="html")
```
]

# Demand Curve

.pull-left[

- .shout[Demand curve] graphically represents the demand schedule

- Also measures a person's .onfire[maximum willingness to pay (WTP)] for a given quantity

- Law of Demand (price effect) $\implies$ Demand curves always slope downwards

]

.pull-right[

```{r, fig.retina=3}
library("mosaic")
demand=function(x){10-x}

ggplot(data.frame(x=c(0,10)), aes(x=x))+
  stat_function(fun=demand, geom="line", size=2, color = "blue")+
  geom_label(aes(x=8,y=demand(8)), color = "blue", label="Demand", size = 6)+
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(0,10,1),
                     limits=c(0,10),
                     expand=expand_scale(mult=c(0,0.1)))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,10,1),
                     limits=c(0,10),
                     expand=expand_scale(mult=c(0,0.1)),
                     labels = function(x){paste("$", x, sep="")})+
  coord_cartesian(clip="off")+
  labs(x = "Quantity of x",
       y = "Price of x")+
  theme_classic(base_family = "Fira Sans Condensed", base_size=20)
```

# Inverse Demand Function

.pull-left[

- .shout[*Inverse* demand function] relates price to quantity
    - Find by taking demand function and solving for $p$

.content-box-green[
.green[**Example**]: 
$$p=10-q$$
]
- Graphable (price on vertical axis)!

- Slope: $-1$

- Vertical intercept called the .shout["Choke price"]: price where $q_D=0$ ($10), just high enough to discourage *any* purchases
    - Quite useful later!

.pull-left[

    - Find by taking demand function and solving for $p$

.content-box-green[
.green[**Example**]: 
$$p=10-q$$
]
- Read two ways:

- Horizontally: at any given price, how many units person wants to buy

- Vertically: at any given quantity, the .shout[maximum willingness to pay (WTP)] for that quantity
    - This way will be very useful later

# Deriving a Demand *Function* I

- I will always give you a (linear) demand function

- Today's class notes page shows how you can derive actual demand functions from utility functions

---

# Deriving a Demand *Function* II

.content-box-red[
.red[**MATH FYI**]: for a Cobb-Douglas utility function (where the two exponents sum to 1):
$$u(x,y)=x^ay^{(1-a)}$$

the **demand function for $x$** is
$$q_x=a\frac{m}{p_x}$$

- Property 1: Consumer always spends proportion $a$ of their total income on $x$! 

- Ptroperty 2: demand for $x$ is unaffected by prices of *other* goods (no $p_y$ anywhere)!

- To get a demand function just in terms of price, input a given income. 

]

---

# Deriving a Demand *Function* III

.pull-left[
.content-box-green[
.green[**Example**]:
$u(x,y)=x^{0.5}y^{0.5}$, demand function is

$$q_x=0.5\frac{m}{p_x}$$

- Always spend 50% $(a)$ of income on $x$

- With an income of $m=10$
$$\text{Demand: }q_x=\frac{5}{p_x} \quad \text{Inv. demand: } p_x=\frac{5}{q_x}$$

- With an income of $m=50$
$$\text{Demand: }q_x=\frac{25}{p_x} \quad \text{Inv. demand: } p_x=\frac{25}{q_x}$$
]
]

.pull-right[
```{r, fig.retina=3, fig.height=5.5}

cd2=function(x){25/x}

ggplot(data.frame(x=c(0,10)), aes(x=x))+
  stat_function(fun=cd1, geom="line", size=2, color = "blue")+
  stat_function(fun=cd2, geom="line", size=2, color = "blue", linetype="dashed")+

  geom_label(aes(x=8,y=cd2(8)), color = "blue", label="Demand: m=40", size = 6)+
    scale_x_continuous(breaks=seq(0,10,1),
                     limits=c(0,10),
                     expand=expand_scale(mult=c(0,0.1)))+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=seq(0,10,1),
                     limits=c(0,10),

  coord_cartesian(clip="off")+
```

# Shifts in Demand II

.pull-left[

- A change in one of the .onfire["determinants of demand"] (or "shifters") will shift the demand curve
    - Change in income $m$
    - Change in price of other goods $p_y$ (substitutes or complements)
    - Change in preferences or expectations about good $x$ (show up in utility function)
    - Change in number of buyers in market

- Shows up in (inverse) demand function by a **change in the intercept (choke price)**! 

- See my [Visualizing Demand Shifters](https://ryansafner.shinyapps.io/Demand/)

]

